q1.description: Below is an example of a DFA.
q1.question: A DFA can proccess inputs from left to right OR right to left.

q3.description: A DFA starts from the left and given the input symbol changes states. At the end of proccessing the inupt (no more letters), the DFA can answer "yes" or "no"
q3.question: DFAs can be used to add more letters to the given input.

q2.question: What state is the control unit in?

q5.description: Deterministic in this context has a particular meaning: When the DFA is in a given state, there is only one thing that it can do for any given input symbol. This is in contrast to a non-deterministic machine, that might have some range of options on how to proceed when in a given state with a given symbol.
q5.question: A DFA machine may be a non-deterministic machine.

q6.description: A DFA that tests to see if a string is a valid integer should output "yes" if given 6789 as input.
q6.question: Suppose we have a DFA that tests to see if a string is a valid integer. What will be the result of giving it this input: 23213

q7.question: Suppose we have a DFA that tests to see if a string is a valid Java identifier. Which of the following will be REJECTED by this proposed DFA?

text.description:
Define a DFA as $(Q, \Sigma, \delta, Q_0, F)$ where
$Q$ is a finite set of states
$\Sigma$ is the input alphabet (a finite set)
$\delta: Q \times\Sigma \rightarrow Q$ is a set of transitions like $(q_i, a) \rightarrow q_j$ meaning that when in state $q_i$, if you see letter $a$, consume it and go to state $q_j$
$q_0$ is the intial state ($q_0 \in Q$)
$F \subseteq Q$ is a set of final states.

q4.description: We interpret the DFA as outputting a value of "yes" on a given input string if the DFA ends processing of that string in a final state, and we say that the DFA outputs "no" if it is not in a final state at the end of processing that string. (Note: Yes/No is synonymous with Accept/Reject)
q4.question: A DFA can end in different states given the same string as the input.

q8.description: $Q$ is a set of all the states of a DFA. Graphically it is all the states/circles.
q8.question: Which of the following represents $Q$?

q9.description: $F$ is a set of all the final states. Graphically depicated as states with an extra circle around them.
q9.question: Which of the following represents $F$?

q10.description: $\Sigma$ is the set of the input alphabet used for the DFA. Graphically depicated as all the symbols on the transitions lines.
q10.question: Which of the following represents the alphabet set $\Sigma$?

q11.description: $Q_0$ is the start state of a DFA. Graphically an arrow/ triangle points to this state.
q11.question: Which of the following represents the start state $q_0$?

q12.description: $\delta$ is the transtions between the states in the form $(q_i, a) \rightarrow q_j$. Example of a move: $\delta(q0, 1) = q0$
q12.question: What is $\delta$(q0,0)?

q13.description: $\delta$ is the transtions between the states. Example of a move: $\delta(q0, 1) = q0$
q13.question: What is  $\delta$(q1,1)?

q14.description:
$\delta$ is sometimes expressed in tabular format to show all possible transitions. $\begin{array}{r|cc}
      & 0  & 1 \\
      \hline
      q0 &  &  \\
      q1 &  &  \\
      \end{array}$
q14.question: Which of these is the $\delta$ for the DFA graph?
answer:
\begin{array}{r|cc} & 0 & 1
 \\ \hline q0 & q1 & q0 \\ q1 & q1 & q0 \\ \end{array}
choices:
\begin{array}{r|cc} & 0 & 1 \\ \hline q0 & q0 & q0 \\ 
q1 & q1 & q1 \\ \end{array}

\begin{array}{r|cc} & 0 & 1
 \\ \hline q0 & q1 & q0 \\ q1 & q1 & q0 \\ \end{array}

\begin{array}{r|cc} & 0 & 1 \\ \hline q0 & q0 & q1 \\ q1
 & q0 & q1 \\ \end{array}

q15.description: We can assign semantic meaning to the states: the machine is in state $q_0$ when the digits proccessed so far make an odd number, and the machine is in state $q_1$ when the digits processed so far make an even number.
q15.question: Which of the following strings will be accepted?

q21.description: When making a transition not shown in the diagram, then the string is not accepted.
q21.question: Which of the following strings will be accepted?

q22.description: A complete DFA has a transition for every alphabet in $\Sigma$ for all states.
q22.question: An incomplete DFA can be made complete by adding a trap state?

text11.description: Lets practice the DFA algorithm by tracing the acceptance or rejections of some strings. The given machine can accept any even number.

q16.description: The DFA below only accepts even number inputs.
q16.question: What state will we start in? (Hint: what is $Q_0$)

q17.description: Step 1: Initially, the tape head is at the leftmost tape cell with character '1', and the current state is q0
q17.question: What state will we move to next?

q18.description: Step 2: The tape head shifts right one cell. The current state remains in q0.
q18.question: What state will we move to next?

q19.description: Step 3: The tape head shifts right one cell. The current state changes to q1.
q19.question: What state will we move to next?

q20.description: Since the last character of the string has now been processed, the machine is done with this input.
q20.question: What does the DFA do?
